title: Baseball Weighs Drug Policy Changes After Pitcher’s Autopsy
text:
Major League Baseball and its players’ union expect to discuss changes to the sport’s drug program after an autopsy report revealed that Los Angeles Angels pitcher Tyler Skaggs had oxycodone, fentanyl and alcohol in his system when he was found dead on July 1.

Under the current agreement, MLB players aren’t tested for what are known as drugs of abuse—which include opioid painkillers—unless there is reasonable cause to do so.

“For several reasons, including the tragic loss of a member of our fraternity and other developments happening in the country as a whole, it is appropriate and important to re-examine all of our drug protocols relating to education, treatment and prevention,” Major League Baseball Players Association Executive Director Tony Clark said.

The cause of Skaggs’ death in a Texas hotel room has sent the baseball industry racing to understand not only the circumstances surrounding his overdose but also the presence of opioids in the sport. Especially alarming to league and union officials was a statement put out by the Skaggs family last week that suggested that an Angels employee might have been involved in providing access to the drugs.

Opioid painkillers, which include such prescription medications as Vicodin and Percocet, are at the center of the nation’s foremost public-health crisis, which has resulted in the deaths of tens of thousands of Americans each year.

Professional baseball players fit the demographic of those most commonly affected by opioid addiction. They are young, and their jobs frequently leave them with pain to manage. Skaggs, who was about two weeks away from his 28th birthday when he died, had an extensive injury history, including Tommy John elbow surgery in 2014.

“Individuals in occupations where they’re prone to injury are more likely to be exposed to opioids and are more likely to become addicted,” said Dr. Andrew Kolodny, the executive director of Physicians for Responsible Opioid Prescribing.

Nonetheless, MLB doesn’t believe the league has a widespread opioid problem. Minor-leaguers, who aren’t represented by the players’ union, are tested regularly for drugs of abuse. Of the roughly 75,000 tests administered in the past five years, only 10 came back positive for opioids.

In the last two rounds of collective bargaining, MLB has proposed mandatory testing for drugs of abuse. Though players have been receptive to expanded testing for performance-enhancing drugs, they have so far resisted more testing for other substances, citing privacy concerns.

Baseball considers any substance classified as Schedule I and II as defined by the U.S. Controlled Substances Act as a “drug of abuse.” That includes marijuana, which is legal for recreational use in some states. It is conceivable that talks between MLB and the players’ union would involve more testing for certain drugs, such as opioids, but not others.

“MLB reviews and updates its drug programs regularly, including an annual review of the Joint Drug Program at the end of each season with the Players Association,” MLB said in a statement. “This year, that review will include a thorough review of the Drug of Abuse aspects of our Joint Drug Program, as well as the content and delivery of our player education programs prior to next season.”

Doctors registered with the Drug Enforcement Administration and having a state license can prescribe players an opioid painkiller for short-term use without triggering the reasonable-cause clause that would prompt further testing.

In recent years, MLB has provided guidance to teams reiterating that they can’t travel with any controlled substance and explaining storage and record- keeping requirements if a player is prescribed with one. The memo also emphasizes that athletic trainers can’t dispense or administer any controlled substance, nor can a physician

In practice, however, players aren’t typically prescribed opioid painkillers by team-affiliated doctors. Several players said in recent interviews that the strongest medication they had ever been prescribed for pain was an anti-inflammatory, such as Voltaren. A player can theoretically apply for a therapeutic-use exemption to allow long-term use of a banned drug, though the league hasn’t granted one for opioids.

The Skaggs family has hired prominent Texas attorney Rusty Hardin as police in Southlake, Texas, continue to investigate Skaggs’ death.

Write to Jared Diamond at jared.diamond@wsj.com
